title: $Guide to Neighbourhood Planning$
body:
$ 

]]>Among many other changes The Localism Act 2011 introduced new rights and powers to allow local communities to shape new development by coming together to prepare neighbourhood plans and Neighbourhood Development Orders.

What is a Neighbourhood Forum?

Neighbourhood planning can be taken forward by two types of body - town and parish councils or 'neighbourhood forums'. Neighbourhood forums are community groups that are designated to take forward neighbourhood planning in areas without parishes
body:summary:
as in the case of the Royal Borough.

A Neighbourhood Forum is an organisation that is established to promote the social
body:format: economic and environmental well-being of an area and has membership which is open to people who live
body:language:
work and those who are elected to represent the area concerned.

Prospective Neighbourhood Forums must apply to the Council to be designated.

What is a Neighbourhood Area?

A Neighbourhood Area is the geographical area that a Neighbourhood Plan or a Neighbourhood Development Order covers. The Neighbourhood Area must be designated by the Council and there cannot be more than one Neighbourhood Plan relating to a Neighbourhood Area
field_contact_button:
and areas cannot overlap.

Prospective Neighbourhood Forums must apply to the Council for a Neighbourhood Area to be designated. This application can be made at the same time as
field_contact_button:title: or separately from
field_contact_button:attributes:
an application to be a Neighbourhood Forum.

What is a Neighbourhood Plan?

A Neighbourhood Plan sets out policies in relation to development and use of land in a particular Neighbourhood Area. Neighbourhood Plans are not developed by the Council but they do have to be in general conformity with Council’s Core Strategy and the London Plan. They are intended to be tools for positive planning
field_contact_button:language:
not a way of preventing development and in particular they cannot introduce controls that are additional to existing planning law and regulations.
Following consultation and examination a Neighbourhood Plan would be approved if it
received more than 50% of the votes cast in a referendum.

What is a Neighbourhood Development Order?

A Neighbourhood Development Order sets out the type of development that can take
place a particular Neighbourhood Area without the need for a planning application to be
made.

As with Neighbourhood Plans
field_publish_date:
Neighbourhood Development Orders would be subject to
consultation
field_publish_date:timezone:
examination and a referendum before they are approved.

title: $How to designate a Neighbourhood Forum and a Neighbourhood Area$
body:
$ 

]]>To designate a Neighbourhood Forum

Neighbourhood forums are community groups that are designated to take forward neighbourhood planning in areas without parishes. It is our role to agree who should be the neighbourhood forum for the neighbourhood area.

To apply you will need:

  • The name of your proposed neighbourhood forum
  • A map of the neighbourhood area
  • Contact details of at least one member of the forum that can be made public
  • A copy of the organisation’s written constitution
  • Statement* that explains that the forum:
    • is established for the purpose of promoting or improving the social
body:summary:
economic and environmental well-being of an area that consists of or includes the neighbourhood area concerned
  • its membership is open to anyone who lives or works in the neighbourhood area or is an elected member of the Council
body:format:
• its membership includes a minimum of 21 people who live or work in the neighbourhood area or are an elected member of the Council
  • it has a written constitution

    • To designate a Neighbourhood Area

    A Neighbourhood Area is the geographical area that a Neighbourhood Plan or a Neighbourhood
    Development Order will cover. If your organisation wants to designate a Neighbourhood Area you will need to apply providing the following information:

    1. A map of your proposed neighbourhood area
    2. A statement explaining why the area is appropriate
    3. A statement* that the organisation making the area application is either a designated forum
body:language:
or is capable of being such

*Further information available in Section 61F(5) and 61G(2) TCPA 1990 Act of the regulations
 
Please note you can apply to designate a Neighbourhood Area and Neighbourhood Forum at
the same time.

]]>Before submitting a neighbourhood plan proposal to the Council
body:summary:
you must publicise your proposal. It must be available to anyone who lives or works in the area for a minimum period of six weeks and give people the opportunity to comment.

Publicise your proposal

You could do this by putting your plan on your neighbourhood forum website
body:format:
in local libraries or
hosting a consultation event. Even better you could leaflet every home and business in your area

Information you must make available: 

  • Details of the neighbourhood plan proposals 
  • Details of where and when the neighbourhood plan proposals can be seen 
  • Details of how to comment on the plan 
  • The date by which comments must be received 

Tell the right people

This plan will affect all living and working in the area
body:language:
so it is important that they are all consulted.
Consider how you will ensure different groups will be able to have their say.
Different groups you may need to make a special effort to contact might include:

  • Community groups and societies 
  • Faith groups 
  • Disabled groups 
  • Local businesses 
  • Young people 
  • Older people 
  • Voluntary bodies acting in the area

You should consider consulting other bodies whose interests may be affected by your neighbourhood
plan. These might be:

  • Mayor of London
  • The Homes and Communities Agency 
  • Natural England 
  • The Environment Agency 
  • English Heritage 
  • Network Rail Infrastructure Limited 
  • The Highways Agency

A more comprehensive list can be found legislation.gov.uk

title: $Is a Neighbourhood Plan right for you?$
body:
$The key to developing and delivering a Neighbourhood Plan is having a clear purpose. A neighbourhood plan is a planning policy document. It would be one of a suite of policy documents against which planning applications in your local area would be assessed. So you need to think about your aims and ambitions and whether these can be delivered through planning policy.

Neighbourhood Planning is optional so you should not feel your area will miss out if it
does not have a Neighbourhood Plan. The Council’s Core Strategy has identified and
planned for a number of ‘places’
body:summary:
these may be sufficient in themselves or they can be
built upon with neighbourhood plans.

The Council has a number of other means of getting involved in making improvements
in your local area like City Living Local Life or Conservation Area Appraisals which may be an easier way to make a difference in your area. A Neighbourhood Plan is produced by local people
body:format:
not the local authority. This can be time consuming and resource intensive so you need to be realistic about what you might be undertaking.

Just as the Council is required to consult when preparing policy
and development plans
body:language:
it is essential that community groups do the same to ensure
that the neighbourhood plan expresses the wishes of the whole community.

title: $What support can the Council provide?$
body:
$The Council is not required to provide financial help to support neighbourhood planning but we will provide some technical advice to assist neighbourhoods in drawing up their proposals.

Neighbourhood Plans should be prepared by Neighbourhood Forums not the Local
Planning Authority. We have a Neighbourhood Planning team who are responsible for area-based planning policy in the borough including supporting our major town centres. Their priority is to
achieve the Council’s objectives set out in the Core Strategy and their capacity to take
on additional work is limited. The Neighbourhood Planning team can provide the following support.

We will:

  • Meet with you to explain the Neighbourhood Planning system and check that this is the best way to achieve your ambitions.
  • Advise on how to apply to become a Neighbourhood Forum and a Neighbourhood Area.
  • Advise on any funding that may be available to support the Neighbourhood Plan e.g. CLG Frontrunners or City Living Local Life Ward Funds. We will apply for funding for the Neighbourhood Forum if this has to be done by the Local Planning Authority on the Neighbourhood Forum’s behalf.
  • Advise on the draft Neighbourhood Plan
  • Advise the Neighbourhood Forum on how to undertake local consultation on the draft Neighbourhood Plan before it is submitted to the Council.
  • Publicise the Neighbourhood Plan and/or Neighbourhood Development Order.
  • Submit the Neighbourhood Plan for Examination.
  • Support the Examination process.
  • Conduct the referendum.

You can contact the neighbourhood planning team by email:
neighbourhood.planning@rbkc.gov.uk or call Jo Hammond

Leader on 0207 361 2061.

title: $What happens next?$
body: $When we receive your neighbourhood plan and consultation statement we will check the necessary documentation has been provided
body:summary: and publicise it for six weeks
body:format:
inviting representations. We will collate any replies we receive into a report.

Examination

We will then arrange for the draft neighbourhood plan to be examined by an independent examiner. The examiner will test whether the draft neighbourhood plan meets the basic conditions and other matters set out in paragraph 8 of schedule 4B of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). The examiner can agree that the plan meets these requirements
body:language:
request changes to the plan to enable it to meet the requirements (which the Council must make) or decide that it does not meet the requirements and cannot be changed in order to meet them.

Referendum

If the examiner is satisfied the plan meets the requirements
field_contact_button: then the Council will organise a referendum. Anyone living in the neighbourhood area who is normally eligible to vote in local elections will be eligible to vote in the referendum. Polling arrangements will be the same as for elections
field_contact_button:title:
although the polling station may be in a different location.

Making the Plan

If the majority of those voting in the referendum vote in favour of the draft neighbourhood plan becoming part of the Council's Local Development Framework
field_contact_button:attributes: then it will be brought into legal force by the Council via a key decision taken by the Cabinet Member for Planning Policy
field_contact_button:language:
Transport and Arts.

title: $How the Council will make decisions$
body:
$There are five stages in neighbourhood planning where the Council needs to make a decision:

1. Decision to consult on an application for designation as a forum and /or an area

This decision is based on checking the correct information has been provided and that the body has an appropriate constitution and areas don't overlap. These are matters of fact and as such will be delegated decisions taken by the Executive Director of Planning and Borough Development.

2. Decision to designate an area or forum

This is a decision based on responses to formal consultation undertaken by the Council and is likely to have a 'significant impact on the community' so will be a Key Decision taken by the Cabinet Member for Planning or the Cabinet.

3. Decision to publicise a neighbourhood plan

When a draft neighbourhood plan is submitted to the Council
body:summary:
the Council is responsible for checking the neighbourhood plan has met the requirements and includes each of the documents referred to in the regulations. These are matters of fact and as such will be delegated decisions taken by the Executive Director of Planning and Borough Development.

4. Decision to submit a neighbourhood plan for examination

The Council is responsible for checking that the submitted Neighbourhood Plan has followed the proper legal process
body:format: such as the neighbourhood area being designated and that the plan has met the legal requirements for consultation and publicity. These are matters of fact
body:language:
but as this is also a significant decision in the process following which the Council will have limited opportunities to reject a plan at a later stage this will be a Key Decision taken by the Cabinet Member for Planning or the Cabinet.

5. Decision to adopt a neighbourhood plan after examination and referendum

Although there are limited grounds on which a decision can be taken to refuse to adopt/make a neighbourhood plan there still needs to be a decision and the reasons for that decision given. Section 38A(6) of the PCPA 2004 provides that the Council is not subject to the duty to make a plan following a referendum in favour of adoption if it considers that the making of the plan would breach or be incompatible with an EU obligation or Convention rights. In view of this the decision to adopt a neighbourhood plan will be a Key Decision taken by the Cabinet Member for Planning or the Cabinet.

title: $Children in Entertainment Overview$
body:
$Children in Entertainment Overview

1) Introduction

1.1 A performance licence issued by a local authority is required for children of any age up to 16 years. The licence allows the child to perform either in: theatre
body:summary: filming
body:format: modelling
body:language: voice over
field_contact_button:
commercials etc. There are a number of different legislations that apply to entertainment performances. They include:

Children and Young Persons Act 1933

Children and Young Persons Act 1963;

Children (Performances) Regulations 1968; (Amended 1998 and 2000)

Television Act 1964;

1.2 A child will need a licence before they can accept perform;

1.3 The purpose of the licence is to ensure that all children are adequately safeguarded and supported.

2) Guidance

2.1 The Attendance (statutory)
field_contact_button:title: Child employment and entertainment
field_contact_button:attributes:
Elective home education and children missing education service (ACE) will consider a number of standards that the licence holder must meet before a licence can be issued.

2.2 Where a child will be absent from school to perform
field_contact_button:language: the Head or Deputy Headteacher at the child’s school must consent to the absence and provide a letter to the licensing authority. The school is consenting to authorising the child’s absence for the agreed period for which the licence cover. Under the regulations
field_publish_date:
such absence must be recorded in the school register as authorised using registration code: C

2.3 The licensing authority shall not grant a licence unless they are satisfied that the child's education will not suffer. Where a school declines to consent to a child’s absence
field_publish_date:timezone: they must be able to prove to the LA that the child’s education will suffer as a result of being absent to engage in a performance. The school may demonstrate this by for example
field_publish_date:rrule: missing homework
field_publish_date:to: slipping grades
field_expiry_date: inability to catch up on work
field_expiry_date:timezone:
missing additional days due to tiredness or unexplained absences etc. If this is the case the Children in Entertainment Officer will refuse the application.

Where a school has raised concerns with the LA’s school support officer regarding frequency of absence to attend performances and auditions the Officer may make contact with the agency / applicant to request that future appointments are offered outside school time.

2.4 Any school absence due to an unlicensed performance will be recorded as an unauthorised absence on the child’s attendance record.

2.5 A tutor must be supplied
field_expiry_date:rrule: where appropriate
field_expiry_date:to:
on longer productions. The tutor must be registered with a licensing authority and hold valid Disclosure & Barring Service (DBS) checks. It is the responsibility of the licence holder to negotiate educational arrangements/support with the headteacher prior to the licence application.

title: $Guidelines to Proceedings in the Magistrates$
body:
$GUIDELINES FOR PROCEEDINGS IN THE MAGISTRATES COURT

1. Introduction

a) Legal proceedings for failure to ensure regular attendance at school are initiated in the Magistrates Court under Education Act 1996 s444.

b) ACE co-ordinates legal action on behalf of the Local Authority for Localities/Early Help services and schools.

c) In any non- attendance case
body:summary: the family should be provided with ACE leaflet
body:format: ‘School Attendance what parents and carers need to know’ which advises them of their legal responsibilities for ensuring their child receives full-time education provision. It also informs them that
body:language: should legal proceedings be initiated for non- attendance
field_contact_button:
evidence contained in a witness statement will refer to information taken from discussions with them. Evidence prior to this notification cannot be used in the prosecution.

d) A decision will need to be made whether or not it is in the public interest to pursue a prosecution prior to initiating legal proceedings.

2. Witness Statement

a) The witness statement is a statement of facts of the case within a six month timescale. Statements must be brief and to the point. In terms of the rules of evidence
field_contact_button:title:
hearsay evidence is not permissible; therefore it is important that evidence is gathered by one person.

b) Staff in Localities/Early Help services prepare a witness statement and are witnesses to the offence being committed.

c) The witness statement needs to give details of parent/carers forenames as well as surnames.

d) Distance can be used as a defence in proceedings by parent/carers. It is therefore important that the issue is addressed in the witness statement.

e) The statement must state whether or not the school where the pupil is enrolled is within walking distance from the pupil’s home i.e.

3.218688 kilometres or 2 miles – if child is under 8 years old

4.828032 kilometres or 3 miles- if child is over 8 years old.

f) If the school is not within walking distance the statement must specify the reasons. Parental preference is often the reason given by parent/carers for a child not attending a school near to home. In such cases
field_contact_button:attributes:
the statement should make reference to arrangements that can and could be made by the Local Authority to support attendance e.g. ‘enabling him to become a pupil at a school nearer to home’ (Education Act 1996 s444).

g) The Local Authority can only initiate proceedings for non- attendance for those absences that have not been authorised by the head teacher or a delegated member of school staff. School staff make the decision whether or not to authorise absences. Any absences that have been substantiated by a medical professional must be authorised and therefore cannot be used in evidence in proceedings for non- attendance.

h) The witness statement must make reference to the reasons why a prosecution is being pursued as opposed to an application for an Education Supervision Order.

i) Certificates of Attendance covering the period should be completed and signed by the head teacher of the school and submitted with the statement and referred to as ‘Annexe 1’. ACE will obtain these once the period of evidence has been agreed.

j) Copies of letters referred to in the statement should be attached to the statement and referred to as ‘Annexe 2’
field_contact_button:language:
‘Annexe 3’ etc. The content of letters does not need to be re-iterated in the witness statement.

k) The statement should confirm that the witness has checked the register and the pupil’s name appears in the register
field_publish_date:
as confirmation that the child is a registered pupil at the school.

3. Parenting Orders The Magistrates Court has the power to make Parenting Orders and therefore The Parenting Order Assessment Form needs to accompany all witness statements. The form should make reference to the parent or carer’s response to receiving support which will be useful when magistrates consider whether or not to make a Parenting Order.

4. Process for legal action in Magistrates Court

a) Referral to ACE for legal action form should be completed by Locality/Early Help managers or headteacher

b) ACE will respond to requests within 5 school days of receiving the request for consideration of a referral for prosecution.

c) ACE will prepare the Notification of intention to prosecute letter to be served by witness to parent/ carer and forward proforma for legal action to be completed by witness.

d) The completed witness statement
field_publish_date:timezone:
annexes and Parenting Order Assessment Form should be prepared and sent to ACE for processing in conjunction with each respective borough’s Legal Services.

e) ACE will that check that court papers are compliant with the rules of evidence
field_publish_date:rrule:
approve them for legal action and then forward to Legal Services.

f) Legal Services will acknowledge receipt of the case for prosecution and issue a summons accordingly.

g) Witnesses will be expected to attend the Magistrates Court to provide evidence where defendants plead not guilty to the offence.

5. Possible outcomes of legal action;

a) Fines – amount of fine is determined by the courts (up to £2500 for s.444(1a) offence).

b) Imprisonment of up to 3 months (for s.444(1a) offence)

c) Conditional discharge – parent/carer receives no punishment on the condition that
field_publish_date:to: in a period set by the court (not more than three years)
field_expiry_date: no further offence is committed. If any offence is committed during the period
field_expiry_date:timezone:
the offender may also be re-sentenced for the original offence for which the conditional discharge was given.

d) Absolute discharge – no conditions attached
field_expiry_date:rrule:
case dismissed.

e) Parenting Order – Parent/carers can be made the subject of a Parenting Order for a period specified by the courts. The conditions of a Parenting Order will require parent/carer to attend parenting sessions
field_expiry_date:to:
arranged by the supervising officer that would support parent/carers in order to prevent them re-offending.

title: $Penalty Notice Code of Conduct$
body:
$1. LEGAL BASIS

1.1 The Anti-social Behaviour Act 2003 s23 empowers designated Local Authority (LA) officers
body:summary: head teachers (and deputy and assistant head teachers authorised by them)
body:format:
and the Police to issue penalty notices in cases of unauthorised absence from school.

1.2 The Education (Penalty Notices) (England) Regulations 2004 came into force on 27th February 2004.

1.3 The issuing of penalty notices must conform to all requirements of the Human Rights Act 2000 and all equal opportunities legislation.

1.4 London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham (LBHF)
body:language:
Royal Borough of Kensington & Chelsea (RBKC) and City of Westminster (WCC) have the prime responsibility for developing the Code of Conduct within which all partners named in the Act will operate.

1.5 In the three boroughs the ACE team is responsible for co-ordinating legal action in relation to school attendance.

2. RATIONALE

2.1 Regular and punctual attendance at school is both a legal requirement and essential for pupils to maximise their educational opportunities.

2.2 In law an offence occurs if a parent or carer fails to secure a child’s regular attendance at a school at which he or she is a registered pupil. Penalty notices supplement the existing sanctions to enforce attendance at school. These are to prosecute parents/carers (Education Act 1996 s444(1) & 444 (1a)) or to apply for an Education Supervision Order
field_contact_button:
under the Children Act 1989 s36.

2.3 Parent/carers and pupils are supported at school and Local Authority level to overcome barriers to regular attendance through a range of assessment and intervention strategies. Sanctions of any nature are for use only where parental co-operation in this process is either absent or deemed insufficient to resolve the presenting problem.

2.4 Sanctions are used only as a means of enforcing attendance
field_contact_button:title: where there is a reasonable expectation that their use will secure an improvement
field_contact_button:attributes:
and to emphasise the importance of parental responsibility.

3. CIRCUMSTANCES WHERE A PENALTY NOTICE MAY BE ISSUED

3.1 The issue of a Penalty Notice may be considered in cases where a pupil is absent from school and the absence is unauthorised. Penalty Notices can be used by schools as an alternative to a referral to Localities Services and Early Help teams in LBHF
field_contact_button:language:
RBKC and WCC in cases of persistent non-attendance. The issue of a Penalty Notice may be considered appropriate in any of the following circumstances:

  • cases of overt truancy
  • cases of parentally condoned absence
field_publish_date:
where this can be demonstrated
  • instances where parents take children out of school for holidays/leave in term time
field_publish_date:timezone:
without the head teacher’s approval
  • instances of excessive delayed return from holidays/leave in term-time
field_publish_date:rrule:
without prior school agreement
  • persistent lateness (unauthorised)
  • where a child has been excluded from school and is found in a public place during school hours without reasonable justification within the first five days of the exclusion period

    •  

     3.2 To ensure consistent and fair delivery of Penalty Notices within the Tri-borough
field_publish_date:to:
Penalty Notices will be considered in cases of unauthorised absence where:

  • they are likely to be effective in improving attendance rates; and
  • the pupil concerned has failed to attend school regularly over a six week period (when his/her attendance has fallen below 85%) and/or
  • holiday/leave is deliberately taken in term time despite permission not being granted by school staff and holiday/leave amounted to 9.5 or more sessions
field_expiry_date:
or
  • holiday/leave in term-time has been agreed by school staff but pupil arrives back 9.5 or more sessions after the period agreed
field_expiry_date:timezone:
or
  • a holiday/leave in term-time was taken
field_expiry_date:rrule:
no permission had been sought and the period of absences amounted to 9.5 or more sessions

3.3 Where families include more than one pupil with poor attendance
field_expiry_date:to: multiple penalty notices may be issued
field_site_section:
but this should be subject to careful consideration and co-ordination.

3.4 For excluded pupils found in a public place during school hours
field_site_section:source_type: individual circumstances of each case must be carefully considered before a decision to issue a Notice. Reasons may include medical emergencies of parent or child
field_site_section:create_term:
or pre-arranged medical appointment.

4. PROCEDURE FOR ISSUING PENALTY NOTICES

4.1 The Tri-borough ACE will implement the issuing of penalty notices on behalf of LBHF
field_site_section:ignore_case:
RBKC and WCC under the authority of the Director of Children’s Services to whom responsibility is delegated by law.

4.2 The Tri-borough ACE will receive a fully completed referral form
field_service_hub:source_type:
and consider written requests to issue penalty notices.

This will ensure that there is;

  • no duplication of notices being served
  • a notice is not issued when legal proceedings are being contemplated under Education Act s444 or an application for an ESO is planned/being made

4.3 Schools
field_service_hub:create_term: the Metropolitan Police and neighbouring Local Authorities must consider every aspect of a pupil’s case before judging whether or not to request the ACE to issue a penalty notice. This must include discussions with other agencies involved
field_service_hub:ignore_case:
including the Early Help and Locality Services and Social Care as well as any other attendance support staff who have knowledge of or involvement with the family before requesting a penalty notice.

4.4 ACE will check that:

  • all relevant information has been provided
  • the circumstances of the pupil’s absence meets all the requirements of this Code of Conduct
  • the issue of a penalty notice does not conflict with other intervention strategies in place or other enforcement sanctions already being processed
  • other support services are appropriately consulted.

4.5 ACE will consider whether the issuing of a penalty notice is likely to improve attendance.

4.6 ACE will consult neighbouring boroughs if a penalty notice is being considered for a parent/carer whose child attends a school in LBHF
field_short_title: RBKC and WCC but resides in another borough. This will ensure consistent and equitable delivery
field_short_title:language:
retain school-home relationships and allow cohesion with other enforcement sanctions.

4.7 Penalty notices will only be issued by post. Penalty notices will not be issued "on the spot" as this does not allow for the collation of evidence.

4.8 ACE will respond to all requests within ten school days of receipt of a referral. If ACE decides that the threshold has been met for a penalty notice to be issued
path:
it will:

  • issue a Penalty Notice without warning from the Local Authority if a holiday/leave is taken without the school’s permission
metatag_title:
during term-time
  • issue a formal written warning to the parent or carer of the possibility of a penalty notice being issued where the occurrence of absence is regular or persistent
  • in the same letter set a period of 15 school days within which the pupil must have no more than 5 or more sessions of unauthorised absence
  • issue a penalty notice at the end of the 15-day period if the required level of improvement has not been achieved

    •  

    5. WITHDRAWAL OF PENALTY NOTICES

    ACE can only withdraw penalty notices in the following limited circumstances:

    5.1 Where it ought not to have been issued i.e. where it has been issued outside the terms of the local code of conduct or where no offence has been committed.

    5.2 Where it has been issued to the wrong person.

    6. PAYMENT OF PENALTY NOTICES

    6.1 Arrangements for payment will be detailed on the penalty notice.

    6.2 Payment of a penalty notice discharges the parents’ or carers’ liability for the period in question. This means that parents or carers cannot subsequently be prosecuted for their failure to ensure that their children are attending school regularly and punctually under other enforcement powers for the period covered by the penalty notice.

    6.3 Payment of a penalty notice within 21 days is £60 and payment after this time but within 28 days is £120. Failure to pay the fine after 28 days will result in consideration being given to prosecution in the Magistrate’s Court.

    6.4 ACE retains any revenue from penalty notices to contribute to enforcement costs (collection or prosecution in the event of non-payment).

    7. NON-PAYMENT OF PENALTY NOTICES

    7.1 Cases of non-payment of a penalty notice
metatag_description:
may trigger consideration of prosecution of parents/carers in the Magistrate’s Court (Education Act 1996 s.444(1) & 444 (1a)).

8. COMMUNICATION AND PUBLICITY

8.1 The establishment of this Code of Conduct should be made available to the school community of the schools intending to use penalty notices.

8.2 In cases where penalty notices are being employed by schools
metatag_standout:
school attendance policies should be revised to include information on the deployment of penalty notices and this will be brought to the attention of all parents.

8.3 ACE will provide a leaflet for schools to distribute to parent/carers explaining the use of penalty notices.

9 REPORTING AND REVIEW

9.1 ACE will report
metatag_rights: on the deployment and outcomes of penalty notices
metatag_image_src:
along with other relevant information about attendance.

9.2 ACE will review penalty notice use at regular intervals using information supplied by schools and propose amendments to the general enforcement strategy as appropriate.

4.1 The Tri-borough ACE will implement the issuing of penalty notices on behalf of LBHF
column71:
RBKC and WCC under the authority of the Director of Children’s Services to whom responsibility is delegated by law.

4.2 The Tri-borough ACE will receive a fully completed referral form
column73:
and consider written requests to issue penalty notices.

This will ensure that there is;

  • no duplication of notices being served
  • a notice is not issued when legal proceedings are being contemplated under Education Act s444 or an application for an ESO is planned/being made

4.3 Schools
column74: the Metropolitan Police and neighbouring Local Authorities must consider every aspect of a pupil’s case before judging whether or not to request the ACE to issue a penalty notice. This must include discussions with other agencies involved
column75:
including the Early Help and Locality Services and Social Care as well as any other attendance support staff who have knowledge of or involvement with the family before requesting a penalty notice.

4.4 ACE will check that:

  • all relevant information has been provided
  • the circumstances of the pupil’s absence meets all the requirements of this Code of Conduct
  • the issue of a penalty notice does not conflict with other intervention strategies in place or other enforcement sanctions already being processed
  • other support services are appropriately consulted.

4.5 ACE will consider whether the issuing of a penalty notice is likely to improve attendance.

4.6 ACE will consult neighbouring boroughs if a penalty notice is being considered for a parent/carer whose child attends a school in LBHF
column76: RBKC and WCC but resides in another borough. This will ensure consistent and equitable delivery
column77:
retain school-home relationships and allow cohesion with other enforcement sanctions.

4.7 Penalty notices will only be issued by post. Penalty notices will not be issued "on the spot" as this does not allow for the collation of evidence.

4.8 ACE will respond to all requests within ten school days of receipt of a referral. If ACE decides that the threshold has been met for a penalty notice to be issued
column78:
it will:

  • issue a Penalty Notice without warning from the Local Authority if a holiday/leave is taken without the school’s permission
column79:
during term-time
  • issue a formal written warning to the parent or carer of the possibility of a penalty notice being issued where the occurrence of absence is regular or persistent
  • in the same letter set a period of 15 school days within which the pupil must have no more than 5 or more sessions of unauthorised absence
  • issue a penalty notice at the end of the 15-day period if the required level of improvement has not been achieved

    •  

    5. WITHDRAWAL OF PENALTY NOTICES

    ACE can only withdraw penalty notices in the following limited circumstances:

    5.1 Where it ought not to have been issued i.e. where it has been issued outside the terms of the local code of conduct or where no offence has been committed.

    5.2 Where it has been issued to the wrong person.

    6. PAYMENT OF PENALTY NOTICES

    6.1 Arrangements for payment will be detailed on the penalty notice.

    6.2 Payment of a penalty notice discharges the parents’ or carers’ liability for the period in question. This means that parents or carers cannot subsequently be prosecuted for their failure to ensure that their children are attending school regularly and punctually under other enforcement powers for the period covered by the penalty notice.

    6.3 Payment of a penalty notice within 21 days is £60 and payment after this time but within 28 days is £120. Failure to pay the fine after 28 days will result in consideration being given to prosecution in the Magistrate’s Court.

    6.4 ACE retains any revenue from penalty notices to contribute to enforcement costs (collection or prosecution in the event of non-payment).

    7. NON-PAYMENT OF PENALTY NOTICES

    7.1 Cases of non-payment of a penalty notice
column80:
may trigger consideration of prosecution of parents/carers in the Magistrate’s Court (Education Act 1996 s.444(1) & 444 (1a)).

8. COMMUNICATION AND PUBLICITY

8.1 The establishment of this Code of Conduct should be made available to the school community of the schools intending to use penalty notices.

8.2 In cases where penalty notices are being employed by schools
column81:
school attendance policies should be revised to include information on the deployment of penalty notices and this will be brought to the attention of all parents.

8.3 ACE will provide a leaflet for schools to distribute to parent/carers explaining the use of penalty notices.

9 REPORTING AND REVIEW

9.1 ACE will report
column83: on the deployment and outcomes of penalty notices
column84:
along with other relevant information about attendance.

9.2 ACE will review penalty notice use at regular intervals using information supplied by schools and propose amendments to the general enforcement strategy as appropriate.

body: $Section 23 of the Anti- Social Behaviour Act 2003 introduced amendments to Section 444 of the Education Act 1996 to empower designated LA officers
body:summary: Head teachers (and Deputy or Assistant Head teachers authorised by them)
body:format:
and the Police to issue Penalty Notices (PNs) in cases of unauthorised absence from school. PNs supplement the existing sanctions currently available under Section 444 of the Education Act 1996 to enforce attendance at school where appropriate.

PNs are an effective tool as an alternative to prosecution under section 444. The offence that a PN is seeking to penalise parents for is a "failure of their child to attend regularly at the school where the child is a registered pupil" (section 444 Education Act 1996). Parents may discharge their potential liability for conviction for an offence under section 444 by paying a penalty. Attendance (statutory functions)
body:language:
Child Employment/Entertainment & Elective Home Education/Children Missing Education (ACE) will be responsible for the issuing of all PNs on behalf of the Local Authorities.

There is no statutory right of appeal against the issue of a PN.

Relevant Legislation:

Education Act (1996) – Section 444 as amended by the Anti-Social Behaviour Act (2003).

Regulations:

  • Education (Penalty Notice) (England) Regulations (2007)
  • The Education (Penalty Notices) (England) (Amendments) Regulations 2012
  • Education (Penalty Notices) (England) (Amendments) Regulations 2013

Guidance:

DCSF Guidance on Education Related Parenting Contracts
field_contact_button:

Code of Conduct for Penalty Notices revised September 2013.

title: $Key Considerations$
body: $A Penalty Notice (PN) is a suitable intervention in circumstances where the parent/carer is failing to ensure that their child attends school on a regular basis. Sanctions of this nature are for use only where parental co-operation is either absent or deemed insufficient to resolve the problem and are used as a means of enforcing attendance where it is likely that their use will secure an improvement. The key consideration in deciding whether or not to make an application to issue a PN
body:summary:
will be whether it will be effective in improving a child’s attendance.

A PN is an alternative to prosecution and will only be issued where the council is "able and willing" to prosecute (DCSF Guidance on Education Related Parenting Contracts
body:format: Parenting Orders and Penalty Notices
body:language: September 2007
field_contact_button: para 186). Before a PN can be issued
field_contact_button:title: Head Teachers and ACE team must be satisfied that the particular episode of unauthorised absence
field_contact_button:attributes: looked at in the context of the individual child and his/her family
field_contact_button:language: warrants criminal proceedings against the parents. They must also have considered alternative methods of securing attendance. The Tri-Borough PN Code of Conduct in London Borough Hammersmith & Fulham
field_publish_date:
Royal Borough of Kensington & Chelsea and City of Westminster allows only authorised officers of ACE to issue PNs. Police and Head Teachers should not issue PNs except in exceptional circumstances.

If accepted
field_publish_date:timezone: the usual response to a first offence might be a warning letter rather than a penalty. However
field_publish_date:rrule: authorised officers have the discretion to issue a PN for the first offence in circumstances. Once issued
field_publish_date:to: a PN will incur a fine of £60.00 per child if paid within 21 days of receipt of the notice
field_expiry_date: rising to £120.00 per child if paid after 21 days but within 28 days of receipt. If the penalty is not paid in full by the end of the 28 day period
field_expiry_date:timezone: the Local Authority (LA) reserves the right to prosecute the parent(s) for the original offence of failing to secure the regular attendance of their child at their registered school
field_expiry_date:rrule:
not for non-payment of the fine.

The Tri-borough’s PN Code of Conduct recommend issuing no more than "one Penalty Notice resulting from the unauthorised absence of an individual child in any twelve month period". However there may be cases where it is appropriate to issue more than one PN to a family during a 12-month period and these will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

title: $Absence from school - leave in term time$
body: $Under the Education (Pupil Registration) Regulations 2006 (amended by the Education (Pupil Registration) (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2013
body:summary: head teachers have the authority/discretion to authorise absence of a pupil due to exceptional circumstances only. It is not a parental right to take leave during term time
body:format:
the decision lies solely with the head teacher of the registered school. Parents must make a request for leave during term time giving the exceptional circumstances for the request and it is at the head teacher’s discretion to determine whether that request should be granted.

The head teacher must use their discretion
body:language: sparingly
field_contact_button: and each request must be judged on a case-by-case basis. Head teachers should not fetter their discretion by applying policies (ie. blanket bans) which prevent assessment of each application on its individual merits. In the majority of cases
field_contact_button:title:
exceptional circumstances will be deemed to be emergency situation. The head teacher in making a decision whether to grant leave during term time should consider all the circumstances surrounding the request.

Where the child’s attendance is below 95% the school should only authorise term time absences in exceptional circumstances. If a child has been genuinely ill or had authorised absences other than for leave in term time however
field_contact_button:attributes:
these factor should be taken into account when considering an application.

Parent/carers should be advised about the school’s policy in relation to leave during term-time The school should also implement procedures where parents/carers must apply for permission for a term-time absence in advance
field_contact_button:language: wherever possible
field_publish_date:
as it is not good practice to grant permission retrospectively. All requests should be made within an appropriate timeline and all decisions recorded. Schools can make make use of the standard leave request form (Appendix A). Schools should inform parents/carers of the process for applying for exceptional leave in term-time through the usual communication channels.

The following guidelines are suggested for considering applications for leave during term time:

  • any parent requiring an absence for their child
field_publish_date:timezone: for an exceptional reason other than for the purpose of a holiday
field_publish_date:rrule:
should make their application in writing at least two weeks prior to the time they wish to have leave
  • the school should invite parents in to discuss the reasons for the application
field_publish_date:to:
especially when the reasons are unclear
  • the school should reply to all applications in writing stating whether or not the absence has been agreed by the school within 5 days of receiving the application
  • the reason for not authorising a request must be clearly stated and evidence given If leave is granted
field_expiry_date: the length of authorised absence must be clearly stated and dates included so that the parent is informed of what date the pupil should be back in school. The school must indicate the consequences should these times not be adhered to
field_expiry_date:timezone:
including the possibility that the parent may receive a PN
  • changes to this process should only be made in exceptional circumstances (i.e. emergencies)

    • Should a child fail to return to school following a period of leave
field_expiry_date:rrule: the school may
field_expiry_date:to: with the agreement of the LA
field_site_section: and following all statutory checks
field_site_section:source_type:
delete from roll a pupil who meets the following conditions:

i. The child must have been granted leave of absence for an exceptional circumstance and

ii. Failed to attend for a period of ten days immediately following the date of which he/she was due to return and

iii. The school does not have reasonable grounds to believe that he/she is unable to attend school by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause.

iv. The school and LA must have failed
field_site_section:create_term: after reasonable enquiry
field_site_section:ignore_case:
to ascertain their whereabouts.

(from Regulation 8(f) Education (Pupil Registration) (England) Regulations 2006 as amended by the Education (Pupil Registration) (England) Regulations 2013).

If a pupil does not meet all of the above conditions he/she may not be legally removed from the school roll. Please contact the ACE team for further advice on this matter.

title: $Making a Penalty Notice referral - leave in term time$
body:
$The conditions in which a PN application could be made are as follows:

1. Where a family has taken leave without permission and the school is satisfied that the parent knew the procedures
body:summary:
providing the leave is equal to or more than 9 sessions (4 ½ days).

2. Where leave of absence has been agreed and the pupil arrives back equal to or more than 9 sessions (4 ½ days) after the agreed time without explanation.

3. Where no application for leave has been made
body:format:
providing the period of absences equal to or more than 9 sessions (4 ½ days).

A PN will only be considered for unauthorised absence where the LA is able and willing to prosecute and satisfied that there is sufficient evidence to show that an offence under Section 444 has been committed and no PN has been issued in relation to the child within the previous twelve months. A parent may receive a separate PN for each child taken out of school.

The normal response to a first offence would be to issue the family with a PN warning rather than a penalty. However PNs may be issued for the first offence in more serious offences
body:language: for instance when the family regularly take holidays during term time and their period of absence is a continuation of a trend. In cases where a child has been absent for less than 9 sessions (4 ½ days)
field_contact_button:
the ACE team recommend issuing the family with a warning letter as an alternative to making a referral for a PN.

Full information must be provided by schools before the ACE team can consider issuing a PN. A fully completed referral form should be forwarded to ACE with all the required evidence attached. (Appendix B). Once this information has been received then the request will be considered by the ACE Team. All referrals will normally be actioned within 10 working days of receipt and a response will be provided to the referring school. Please see appendix C for a flow-chart of action following referral.

Once a PN has been issued
field_contact_button:title:
parents often contact the ACE team with a variety of reasons why it should not have been issued. Providing in-depth referral information would assist our service with managing these issues.

A parent will not normally receive more than one PN resulting from the unauthorised absence of an individual child in any twelve month period. If unauthorised absence persists after the issue of the first PN
field_contact_button:attributes:
it would normally be appropriate to prosecute or address the attendance using an alternative intervention.

Once a PN has been issued
field_contact_button:language:
it may only be withdrawn by the ACE team on behalf of the Local authority in the following circumstances:

  • the Notice has been issued to the wrong person
  • the Notice should not have been issued (for example where evidence has been provided after the notice being issued
field_publish_date:
which covers the period of absence under the conditions of medical absence or unavoidable cause)
  • where the Notice contains material errors (eg: wrong address)
  • in the circumstances of exclusion
field_publish_date:timezone:
reasonable justification has been made out by the parent

There is no specific sanction for the non-payment of a PN
field_publish_date:rrule: and no specific means of enforcement. However
field_publish_date:to: where the penalty has not been paid at the expiry of the period
field_expiry_date: the LA has to consider whether to prosecute the parents for the original offence of "failure of their child to attend regularly at the school where the child is a registered pupil". In the vast majority of cases proceedings would be initiated
field_expiry_date:timezone:
however in consultation with borough Legal Services a number of factors would be considered when taking the decision to prosecute. The most common reason for not continuing with proceedings is incorrect/inconsistent information being provided on the referral form. For this reason it is important to ensure that information provided to the ACE team is correct and up to date.

title: $Penalty Notice referrals for Persistent Absenteeism$
body:
$PNs are an early intervention strategy that can be used as an alternative to referring a case to the Locality /Early Help teams for pupils who are persistently absent from school and where attendance is the only concern. In cases where attendance issues are more entrenched or complex a referral to Locality/Early help team should be made

A PN for persistent absenteeism would only be issued where a pupil has failed to attend school regularly over a six-week period (when his/her attendance has fallen below 85%). This may comprise a series of single or half-day unauthorised absences or a block of unauthorised absences for reasons such as illness where no evidence has been provided.

As with PN referrals for leave during term time
body:summary:
detailed information is required on all applications in order for the ACE team to make an informed decision on whether a PN should be issued. A fully completed form should be forwarded to ACE with all the required evidence.

Once this information has been received then the request will normally be actioned within 10 working days of receipt and a response will be provided to the referring school.

The response to a PN referral for persistent absenteeism is generally to issue a PN Warning
body:format: whereby a 15-day monitoring period would be established in order to give the parent an opportunity to improve their child’s attendance and avoid a subsequent fine. Should the child have 5 or more sessions of unauthorised absence during the 15-day monitoring period
body:language:
a PN will be issued. Please see Appendix C for a flow-chart of action following referral.

A parent will not normally receive more than one PN resulting from the unauthorised absence of an individual child in any twelve month period. If unauthorised absence persists after the issue of the first PN
field_contact_button:
it may be appropriate to prosecute or address the attendance using an alternative intervention.

title: $Penalty Notices for excluded children$
body:
$Section 105 of the Education and Inspections Act 2006 enables PNs to be issued to parents of excluded children who breach the duty to ensure that their child is not present in a public place during the first five days of exclusion without reasonable justification. Reasonable justification will be assessed on the individual circumstances of each case but may include medical emergency of parent or child or pre-arranged medical appointment. Revised regulations and guidance relating to Penalty Notices in cases of truancy and exclusions came into force on 1st September 2007.

There is no limit to the number of PNs that may be issued within a twelve month period for excluded children.

Should you have any questions or concerns please contact the Tri-borough ACE team who will be pleased to advise on these matters.

title: Register-keeping
body:
$1. The Education (Pupil Registration) Regulations 2006 provide statutory regulations for schools relating to maintenance and upkeep of admissions and attendance registers.

2. The Department for Education (DfE) advises that schools are legally required to record in the attendance register once at the beginning of the morning session and once during the afternoon whether the pupil is present
body:summary: absent
body:format: engaged in an approved supervised educational activity off-site
body:language: or unable to attend due to exceptional circumstances as defined in regulation 6(5). If a child of compulsory school-age pupil is absent
field_contact_button: the register should indicate whether the absence is authorised or unauthorised. It must also record the nature of any approved
field_contact_button:title:
supervised educational activities.

3. The law specifies that the school must allow the Local Authority access to inspect school registers and ACE is the designated service that carries out this duty. Outlined below is guidance for register-keeping that additionally provides details of the aspects that will be covered in an inspection.

Guidance for register- keeping and inspections

1. Daily registers
field_contact_button:attributes: using OMR forms or equivalent
field_contact_button:language: and Official Registers
field_publish_date: should be available for inspection. It is good practice to print-off Official Registers
field_publish_date:timezone: on a monthly basis
field_publish_date:rrule: and ensure that they are clearly labelled and maintained in a good condition; however
field_publish_date:to: alternatively they can be stored electronically. It is important to note that Official Registers can be subject to inspection by Ofsted and also be used as evidence
field_expiry_date: if required
field_expiry_date:timezone:
in legal proceedings.

2. Names
field_expiry_date:rrule:
dates of birth and addresses of children should be clearly recorded and available at the time of inspection. The information can be viewed/printed on Registration Certificates. Paper records should also be held in case of emergency evacuations.

3. The totals of unauthorised and authorised absence for each half term should be kept in the Official Register. This information can be used for any required absence returns as well as providing data required for analysis.

4. It is a legal requirement
field_expiry_date:to: as well as having a health and safety component
field_site_section:
that daily registers should be completed up to and including the day of inspection. Morning and afternoon sessions should be recorded each day. It is wholly unacceptable for registers to be completed in advance.

5. Authorised and unauthorised absence and lateness codes should be correctly used and supported where necessary with additional commentary. Additional commentary can be entered into School Information Management System (SIMS) to accompany the absence code. Correspondence can be stored electronically either in SIMS or on the School Network in a clearly identifiable location. Paper correspondence can be held on Pupil’s manual file. In terms 2 of lateness
field_site_section:source_type:
comments and/or minutes late can be entered in SIMS to accompany the Late Code.

6. Evidence of action taken by school staff regarding unauthorised absence needs to be recorded. As noted above
field_site_section:create_term:
comments can be entered in SIMS to accompany the absence code and correspondence can be stored electronically either in SIMS or on the School Network in a clearly identifiable location. Paper correspondence can be held on an individual pupil’s manual file.

7. Systems need to be in place for a school to identify pupils falling into DfE category of ‘persistent absence’. SIMS Attendance reports should be run each week once all attendance marks have been recorded
field_site_section:ignore_case:
using all correct absence codes.

8. All schools have a responsibility to ensure that they have robust IT back-ups in place. This covers both SIMS and any documents on the network. SMS offer advice on back-up solutions. Any further advice on SIMS should be directed to School Management Support Team.  

Removal of Children from the School Roll

The Education (Pupil Registration) (England) Regulations 2006s8 (2f) specify the circumstances when a pupil can be legally be removed from the admissions/attendance register. Unlawful deletions from admissions/attendance register can lead to children missing education as well as vital safeguarding implications. The Z code should be used when a child’s name has been removed from the school roll. Inspections by the Local Authority and Ofsted will pay particular attention to children who have been removed from a school roll.

GOOD PRACTICE GUIDANCE FOR ANALYSING ATTENDANCE DATA AND STARTING APPROPRIATE ACTION

1. It is the responsibility of school staff to have systems in place for regularly analysing school attendance data and starting appropriate action to ensure that both individual and overall school attendance is maintained to a satisfactory level. SIMS would be used to undertake this work.

2. The school attendance lead should explore ways which the SIMS can be used to better understand a school’s attendance profile
field_service_hub:source_type: timely action is taken. The information can be used to tackle both individual school attendance
field_service_hub:create_term: group and school overall attendance. The reports can be produced to look at attendance data on individual pupils as well as analysing particular year groups
field_service_hub:ignore_case:
classes or forms. SIMS can also provide a group analysis based upon categories of attendance codes being used.

3. Ideally attendance data needs to be analysed weekly to swiftly identify trends and patterns of attendance. A recommendation for good practice would be for this to be done weekly to provide an ongoing analysis of attendance to ensure prompt appropriate action is taken about the attendance of individuals
field_short_title: and also to target particular groups of children e.g. classes
field_short_title:language:
year groups etc.

4. School strategies should be employed to tackle an individual pupil’s attendance percentage: telephone contact
metatag_description:
contracts and setting individual attendance targets. SUPPORTING SCHOOL 3 ATTENDANCE: UNAUTHORISED ABSENCE – PLAN OF ACTION provides suggested timescale for appropriate action.

5. Consideration of a request for support from Localities/Early Help services in relation to school attendance should be made in response to attendance percentage below 90% over a 6-week period that has not been improved by school strategies.

6. There will be cases where the timing of a request for support for school attendance should be considered
metatag_generator: if an attendance percentage below 90% has started to improve towards the end of a 6-week period (e.g. child has returned to school following a 2-week or 3-week unauthorised holiday in term-time). Logically the period for monitoring should be further extended to take this into consideration
metatag_rights:
before requesting support for attendance. School staff may also want to consider an earlier referral if the child has more complex needs.

7. Whether or not an absence is authorised is the decision of school staff
metatag_image_src: not parents/carers. School staff should be mindful of not authorising regular or prolonged periods of authorised absence unless it is medically substantiated
metatag_canonical:
and parent/carers should be informed of the decision not to authorise future absences.

8. In terms of regular or prolonged medically-substantiated absence
metatag_shortlink:
consideration needs to be given to the child’s suitability for mainstream educational provision on health grounds. Consideration can be given to a referral for alternative provision being made on health grounds.

9. The information provided is guidance only and any further queries should be addressed to ACE.

title: $Removal from School Roll$
body:
$(The Education (Pupil Registration) (England) Regulations 2006)

Unlawful removal of a child from the roll of a school/academy can be dangerous with potential implications for safeguarding. Please ensure where possible you have confirmation of the new educational provision the pupil is transferring to before removing a child from your roll. You have a duty to inform your local authority and the local authority where the child lives.

Circumstances in which a child can be removed from a school/academy roll:

1. Child is transferred to roll at another place of education and name and address of same has been established. Action: information about child should be passed to staff in the new school and common transfer file (CTF) via s2s website.

2. Child has been absent for 20 continuous school days or more without explanation or authorisation; school/academy has made all reasonable enquiries as to child’s whereabouts and local authority where child resides confirms child cannot be found. Action: child must remain on roll until reasonable enquiries completed
body:summary:
even if this absence exceeds 20 days.

3. Child has failed to return from previously authorised leave within 10 school days of the agreed return date. The total absence period
body:format: including the authorised leave period
body:language:
must be equal to or more than 20 school days. Action: School/academy staff must make sure child does not have good reason for failing to return on agreed date. The school/academy and local authority must make reasonable enquiries to locate child. Child must remain on roll until the enquiries have been concluded

4. Child has ceased to attend school and no longer ordinarily resides at a place which is reasonable distance from the school at which he/she is registered. Action: School/academy must ensure that the new address is obtained from the parent/carer. Appropriate members of staff in the local authority that the child has moved are notified. Members of staff at the school the child has left have received confirmation of receipt of the notification
field_contact_button:
in order that they can ensure that the child is in receipt of education.

5. Parents/carers have withdrawn child from school/academy and have given written notice that child will be educated otherwise than at school*. (It is unlawful for school/academies to encourage parents/carers to educate children at home as a way of avoiding an issue staff in school should be tackling.) Action: If parents/carers indicate desire to educate children at home
field_contact_button:title:
matter should be referred to the Tri-borough ACE team. *This does not apply if a child is attending your school in compliance with a School Attendance Order.

6. Child is in custody for period exceeding four months and there is no reason to think that he/she will return to school at the end of that period. Action: Child detained for purely medical reasons should not be treated as child in custody.

7. Child has been permanently excluded. Action: Removal from roll cannot take place until outcome of any appeal known.

8. Child is medically unfit and will remain so until after his or her official leaving date. Action: School/academy staff must gather substantial medical evidence and work with other agencies to find other suitable education enabling dual registration.

9. Child has died.

*There is different consideration for Special (SEN) schools.

If you need further clarification about removing a child from roll
field_contact_button:attributes: please contact Tri-borough Attendance
field_contact_button:language:
Child Employment/Licensing & Elective Home Education/Children Missing Education (ACE) team.

body: $<?xml version="1.0"?><page_data xmlns="http://rbkc-cms1/edit/" version="5.1"><template>rf-pub-child</template><template_data><![CDATA[]]></template_data><content><contentsbox xmlns=""><![CDATA[<h2>ACE team
body:summary:
Locality Services (LBHF and WCC) and Early Help Team (RBKC)

1. Introduction

a. From July 2013 all Education Welfare Officers across the Tri Borough have been transferred to Locality/Early Help services
body:format:
multidisciplinary teams offering early intervention and preventive support to families and children.

b. If a parent or carer
body:language: member of school staff or other professional is concerned about a child’s school attendance
field_contact_button: he or she should complete the relevant referral form for the respective boroughs Locality/Early Help services
field_contact_button:title:
(3b).

c. The ACE team will retain responsibility for all whole-school statutory services (e.g. register inspections
field_contact_button:attributes:
Penalty Notices) and will also be available to answer school queries on policy and procedure in relation to school attendance.

d. There are
field_contact_button:language: however
field_publish_date:
some specific responsibilities for individual children that ACE will retain. This document is a guide to how ACE and Locality/Early Help staff will work together to support families and children in this borough.

2. Children missing education (CME) or having elective home education (EHE)

a. CME are children who have no educational provision. They are not children who have provision but have poor attendance or those who are approved as electively home educated.

b. Because all LAs have a statutory responsibility to all CME
field_publish_date:timezone:
ACE will be responsible for maintaining a Tri Borough register of all children notified to ACE as out of school (this register includes EHE children as well as CME children).

c. Any professional who identifies a child he or she believes to be either CME or EHE is asked to inform ACE at once in writing
field_publish_date:rrule: providing the child’s name
field_publish_date:to: address
field_expiry_date: date of birth
field_expiry_date:timezone:
and previous educational provision if known.

d. ACE will then work with colleagues as appropriate to ensure CME are placed and EHE families are properly supported using agreed procedures.

e. If any professional has wider concerns about a family whose child is CME or EHE
field_expiry_date:rrule: they will either complete the appropriate Locality/Early Help referral form (4c) or
field_expiry_date:to: if there are child protection concerns

title: $Appeals and reviews$
body: $The Council has a duty to provide advice and help to anyone who is homeless. If you make a homeless application
body:summary: we will consider your individual circumstances to decide what
body:format: if any
body:language: housing duty is owed to you. If you disagree with a decision made on your homeless application
field_contact_button:
you may be able to ask for a review.

Which decisions can I ask to be reviewed?

You are entitled to seek a review of the following decisions on homeless applications (or on the relevant duties owed you as a result of these decisions):

  • eligibility (if the decision is that you are ‘ineligible’ (do not qualify) for assistance due to your immigration or legal status in the UK) 
  • homelessness (if you have been found ‘not homeless’)
  • priority need (if the decision is that you are ‘not in priority need’) 
  • intentionality (if you are considered ‘intentionally homeless’)
  • referral (if the decision is to refer your case to another council – you can ask for a review at two stages in the process
field_contact_button:title:
both when we refer you and when the other council accepts a duty to you)
  • suitability of accommodation (you can only request a review of  the suitability of your temporary accommodation if the Council has accepted a full housing duty)
  • discharge of duty (where the Council decides that no further duty is owed to you because it considers these duties have ended).

    • When can I ask for a review?

    The law says that you must ask for a review within 21 days of the decision. If you are outside this time
field_contact_button:attributes: you do not have a right to a review. We may consider it however
field_contact_button:language:
if you show that exceptional circumstances caused you to be late.

Can I get help with my request for a review?

You may find that an independent legal or specialist housing adviser can help you with this process. Let us know that you are asking for a review as soon as you can
field_publish_date: and then seek this help to save time. You may also wish to provide new information
field_publish_date:timezone: in which case you may need the help of professionals
field_publish_date:rrule: such as social workers or doctors
field_publish_date:to:
who know about your situation.

Who will deal with my review?

Your review will be dealt with by one of the Council’s review officers. This person will be independent of the original decision and experienced in housing law so that they can reach a new decision on your case.

You can contact the review officer either by email to housingreviews@rbkc.gov.uk or alternatively in writing:

Review Officer
Housing Needs Department
Second Floor
The Town Hall
Hornton Street
London W8 7NX

What happens next?

You will receive a letter within one week which acknowledges your request for a review. It will also explain the process. If you do not have an address
field_expiry_date:
this letter (and any others concerning your review) will be kept in the Customer Services Centre at the Town Hall for you to collect. Your case will be examined objectively and independently to make sure that the original decision was reached in a lawful way and was correct based on the information available.

A new ‘review decision’ will be reached. This must take account of your circumstances now and since the original decision was made. We may need to make enquiries and seek further information so this can take time. If you have a solicitor or specialist adviser acting for you
field_expiry_date:timezone:
we will contact them rather than contacting you directly.

How long will it take?

The law allows for up to eight weeks to complete most reviews (and longer for reviews of some referral decisions). However
field_expiry_date:rrule: in some cases the process can take longer and it may be necessary for you
field_expiry_date:to:
your representative or the review officer to ask for an extension to complete the review.

Will I continue to be accommodated?

The Council does not have a duty to accommodate you while the review is being carried out and we do not normally provide accommodation
field_site_section: so you will need to make alternative arrangements. We may have to provide accommodation in exceptional circumstances - where we believe the original decision could be unlawful and may be overturned
field_site_section:source_type:
or where new information puts it in doubt and you would face exceptional hardship without accommodation (more so than other people who are homeless).

What is the law around the review process?

Section 202 of Part 7 of the Housing Act 1996 (amended in 2002) instructs councils how reviews are to be carried out. The procedures for reviews are covered in Statutory Instrument 1999 No. 71. You can find copies of these in your local library
field_site_section:create_term: and housing advisers and solicitors will also keep copies. You can find the law on the <a onclick="window.open(this.href
field_site_section:ignore_case: '_blank'); return false;" href="http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1996/1996052.htm" onkeypress="if (event.keyCode==13) {window.open(this.href
field_service_hub:source_type: along with the <a onclick="window.open(this.href
field_service_hub:ignore_case:
'_blank'); return false;}"> Statutory Instrument.

What if I think the review decision is still wrong?

If you still believe the Council has made an unlawful decision
field_short_title:
the law allows you to seek a County Court Appeal (Section 204 of the 1996 Act). You must apply to the County Court within 21 days of the notification of the review decision and on a point of law. It is recommended that you obtain legal advice if you do seek such an appeal.

$This document is the policy that the Tri Borough Children’s Services will follow regarding elective home education (EHE).

The policy clarifies how the Tri Borough local authorities (LAs) - Westminster
body:summary:
Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith and Fulham - will carry out their duties in respect of children who receive their education at home from their parents/carers or from tutors employed by them.

Parents/carers who have chosen to
body:format: or are considering
body:language: educating their child/ren outside the school system may find it useful to read this policy but it is primarily the EHE ‘Guidance for parents’ document that is intended to provide information and advice to parents/carers on how to proceed
field_contact_button:
what to consider and who to contact for further support and advice.

The Tri Borough ACE team carries out the LA duties regarding EHE. Contact details for the ACE team are:

ACE team Tri Borough Children’s Services

Kensington Town Hall Hornton Street London W8 7NX Phone no: 020 8753 2877

title: Introduction
body: $Elective home education is the term used to describe parents/carers’ decision to provide education for their children at home
body:summary:
instead of sending them to school. This is different to home tuition provided by the local authority or education provided by the local authority other than at school.

The purpose of this policy is to support LA officers in carrying out their statutory responsibilities and to encourage good practice by setting out the legislative position and the roles and responsibilities of LAs and parents/carers in relation to children educated at home.

The LA recognises that there are many approaches to elective home education and parents/carers education provision will reflect a diversity of approaches which will be respected.

title: $Law relating to Elective Home Education$
body:
$Section 7 of the Education Act 1996 states

The responsibility for a child’s education rests with their parents/carers. In England
body:summary: education is compulsory
body:format:
but school is not.

"The parent of every child of compulsory school age shall cause him to receive efficient full-time education suitable:

(a) to his age
body:language: ability and aptitude
field_contact_button:
and

(b) to any special educational needs he may have
field_contact_button:title:
either by regular attendance at school or otherwise."

An "efficient" and "suitable" education is not defined in the Education Act 1996 but "efficient’ has been broadly described in case law1 as education that "achieves that which it sets out to achieve"
field_contact_button:attributes: and a "suitable" education is one that "primarily equips a child for life within the community of which he is a member
field_contact_button:language: rather than the way of life in the country as a whole
field_publish_date:
as long as it does not foreclose the child’s options in later years to adopt some other form of life if he wishes to do so."

There is no legal definition of "full-time". Children normally attend school for between 22 and 25 hours a week for 38 weeks of the year
field_publish_date:timezone: which many parents/carers who are EHE find a useful guide
field_publish_date:rrule:
but there is no set amount of hours that EHE has to take place.

 

1 Mr Justice Woolf in the case of R v Secretary of State for Education and Science
field_publish_date:to:
ex parte Talmud Torah Machzkei Hadass School Trust (12 April 1985)
