title: $Special Educational Needs$
body: $<?xml version="1.0"?><page_data xmlns="http://rbkc-cms1/edit/" version="5.1"><template>rf-pub-child</template><template_data><![CDATA[]]></template_data><content><contentsbox xmlns=""><![CDATA[<ul> <li>Under Section 7 of the Education Act 1996 parents have the right to educate children
body:summary: including children with SEN
body:format: at home. Home education must be suitable to the child’s age
body:language: ability
field_contact_button:
aptitude and SEN. 
  • Parents/carers right to EHE applies equally where a child has Statement of Special Educational Needs or following the legislative changes in Children and Families Act 2014
field_contact_button:title: an Education Health Care (EHC) plan. Where a child has a Statement of SEN or EHC plan and is EHE
field_contact_button:attributes:
it remains the LA’s duty to ensure that the child/young person’s needs are met. 
  • The LA will have regard to the statutory guidance contained within Special Educational Needs and Disability Code of Practice 2015 (s10.30) which emphasises the importance of LAs and other providers working in partnership with parents. Further information in relation to children and young people with SEN who are home educated can be found in s10.30 –s10.38 of the code of practice 2.
  • It is important to note that where the LA and parents agree that home education is the right provision for a child or young person with an EHC plan
field_contact_button:language: the plan should make it clear that the child or young person will be educated at home. Under Section 42(2) of the Children and Families Act 2014
field_publish_date:
the LA must arrange the special education provision set out in the plan.
  • However
field_publish_date:timezone: if the EHC plan gives the name of a school or type of school where the child will be educated and the parents decide to educate at home
field_publish_date:rrule:
the LA is not under a duty to make the special educational provision set out in the plan provided it is satisfied that the arrangements made by the parents are suitable. The LA must review the plan annually to assure itself the provision is appropriate and meeting the child’s needs.
  • If the child/young person is attending a special school
field_publish_date:to:
the LA must give consent for the child’s name to be removed. There is no provision in law for a ‘trial period’ of home education.
  • The LA should not assume that because the provision being made by parents is different from that which was being made or would have been made in the school that the provision is necessarily unsuitable. The LA should also consider using their power to help parents make suitable provision.
  • Young people may also be educated at home in order to meet the requirements to participate in education and training until the age of 18.

    • [2] https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/398815/SEND_Code_of_Practice_January_2015.pdf

title: $Safeguarding and Child Protection$
body:
$The LA has a duty under the section 175 (1) of the Education Act 2002 to safeguard and promote the welfare of children. This section states:

"A local authority shall make arrangements for ensuring that the functions conferred upon them in their capacity as a local authority are exercised with a view to safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children".

Although S175 (1) does not give the LA powers to enter the homes of or otherwise see
body:summary: children for the purposes of monitoring the provision of EHE
body:format:
S10 and S11of the Children Act 2004 gives powers to allow LAs to insist on seeing children in order to enquire about their welfare where there are grounds for concern (sections 17 and 47 of the Children Act 1989).

Although there is no obligation on the LA to ascertain the child’s wishes and feelings about EHE in particular
body:language: S 53 of the Children Act 2004 sets out the duty on LAs to
field_contact_button: where reasonably practicable
field_contact_button:title:
take into account the child’s wishes and feelings.

The safeguarding
field_contact_button:attributes: wellbeing
field_contact_button:language: welfare and protection of children are of paramount importance and a shared responsibility between key professionals and the community as a whole. If any officer of the LA becomes aware or has information that indicates a child is at risk or that their wellbeing is being impaired
field_publish_date:
consultation and a referral will be made in accordance with agreed Safeguarding and Child Protection Procedures.

title: $Roles and responsibilities$
body:
$There will be a designated senior officer from within the ACE team who is familiar with the law and responsible for the policy and practice relating to EHE education; they will advise other colleagues with whom they work on relevant policy and practice.

If notification is received by the ACE team that a child or children are being EHE
body:summary:
a letter will be sent to parents/carers outlining the LAs agreed procedures.

The head teacher of a school is required to immediately inform the LA ACE team of any child on their school roll whose parents/carers have confirmed their intention to EHE3.

The head teacher will be asked to complete a brief report ‘Background information report for children being electively home educated’
body:format: providing details of the child
body:language:
their previous education history etc. and forward this to the ACE team.

The child’s name should not be removed from the school roll until this report has been received
field_contact_button: although removal of the child’s name from the school roll can be backdated as appropriate
field_contact_button:title:
once the ACE have received parent/carers confirmation of their intention to EHE and the schools report.

School staff are advised not to seek to persuade parents to EHE as a way of avoiding exclusion or because a child may have a poor attendance record. Referral to the ‘Questions for professionals to consider’ guidance is strongly recommended.

title: $Local Authorities Responsibilities$
body: $The LA should have a designated senior officer with responsibility for EHE policy and procedures who is familiar with home education law
body:summary:
policies and practices. 

The LA has a duty under section 436A of the Education Act 1996
body:format: inserted by the Education and Inspections Act 2006
body:language: to make arrangements to establish the identities
field_contact_button: so far as it is possible to do so
field_contact_button:title:
of the children in their area who are not receiving a suitable education. 

This duty applies in relation to children of compulsory school age who are not on a school roll and when the LA does not know if a child is receiving a suitable education otherwise than being at school. The parents/carers of all children identified as such will receive a letter from the LA
field_contact_button:attributes:
outlining the LAs procedures in relation to EHE. 

Under Section 437 (1) of the Education Act 1996 the LA will intervene if it appears that a child is not receiving a suitable education but prior to initiating any legal interventions the LA will endeavour to work with parents/carers and will seek to gather any relevant information that will assist the LA in reaching an informed judgement on whether the education being provided is suitable or not.

Information may include a report from a child’s school (if they have been at one) prior to a decision to EHE or a report from a member of the ACE team
field_contact_button:language:
if the parents/carers are prepared to discuss their reasons for EHE or to provide any relevant contextual information. 

In addition
field_publish_date: to minimise the possibility of any unnecessary legal action
field_publish_date:timezone: there is a Tri borough Home Education Adviser (HEA) who will usually arrange to see all EHE families within 90 school days of the LA being informed that a child is being EHE. This allows sufficient time for parents/carers to establish their preferred method of teaching and learning
field_publish_date:rrule:
although it is accepted that they may change their approach over time.

Following any contact with parents/carers
field_publish_date:to:
the LA will write to them stating whether the LA has any concerns about the education provision and specifying what the concerns are. Parents/carers will be given the opportunity to address any concerns that the LA has. 

Where concerns about the suitability of the education have been identified
field_expiry_date:
more frequent contact between the LA and parents/carers may be arranged while the concerns are being addressed. The timing of contact will be discussed and agreed with parents/carers. If there are no concerns annual contact will be offered. 

The HEA will discuss provision with parents/carers and can offer advice on providing a suitable education that meets the best interests of the child but will not stipulate a type of learning or curriculum. 

The HEA may ask to make a home visit in order to discuss the education provision - parents/carers are not required to grant access to their home so a meeting can be arranged at an alternative venue. 

If
field_expiry_date:timezone: after all reasonable steps have been taken to assess the situation
field_expiry_date:rrule: the LA judges that a suitable education is not being provided by the parents/carers and a Notice (which gives no less than 15 days to respond) has been served
field_expiry_date:to:
the LA may serve a School Attendance Order under Section 437 (3) of the Education Act 1996.

"If –

(a) a parent on whom a notice has been served under subsection (1) fails to satisfy the local education authority
field_site_section: within the period specified in the notice
field_site_section:source_type: that the child is receiving suitable education
field_site_section:create_term:
and

(b) in the opinion of the local authority it is expedient that the child should attend school
field_site_section:ignore_case: the authority shall serve an order (referred to in this Act as a "school attendance order" )
field_service_hub: in such a form as may be prescribed
field_service_hub:source_type:
requiring him to cause the child to become a registered pupil at a school named in the order".

At any stage after a School Attendance Order (SAO) has been issued a parent can present information to show suitable education is being provided
field_service_hub:create_term:
the SAO can be revoked.

title: Introduction
body:
$1. Introduction

The purpose of this guidance is to give advice to parents who intend educating their child or children at home. Please note that the term "parents" is used in this guidance to include "parent(s) or carer(s)".

The aim is for contact with home educators to be constructive and positive. We are keen to build relationships that are rooted in mutual understanding
body:summary: trust and respect. We also aim for our procedures dealing with home educating parents and children to be fair
body:format: clear
body:language: consistent
field_contact_button:
non-intrusive and timely.

]]>
field_contact_button:title: |">The Law]]>$
field_contact_button:attributes: Introduction

title: $The Law$
body:
$2. The Law

The education of a child at home is permitted subject to certain conditions imposed by the Education Act 1996 section 7
body:summary:
which states:

"The parent of every child of compulsory school age shall cause him or her to have efficient full-time education suitable to his or her age
body:format:
ability and aptitude (and to any special needs he or she may have) either by regular attendance at school or otherwise."

The phrase "or otherwise" covers proposals for the education of children at home. This means that parents have a legal responsibility to provide their children with a relevant education
body:language:
but that does not have to be in a school.

]]>

title: $Is home educating right for us?$
body: $<?xml version="1.0"?><page_data xmlns="http://rbkc-cms1/edit/" version="5.1"><template>rf-pub-child</template><template_data><![CDATA[]]></template_data><content><contentsbox xmlns=""><![CDATA[<h3>3. Will home educating be right for me
body:summary: my child
body:format:
and the rest of my family?

Most parents and their children find home-educating to be a rewarding experience
body:language: deciding to educate your child at home from the start or to withdraw your child from mainstream schooling and to educate them at home is a major step which will have a significant effect on the organisation of your home life. It might be helpful before making the final decision to consider some of the questions that arise in providing home education
field_contact_button:
for example 

Do I have a secure understanding of what is meant by an "efficient full-time education suitable to his or her age
field_contact_button:title:
ability and aptitude"?

Do I have the time and energy to provide an efficient education?

Can I afford the possible costs of books
field_contact_button:attributes: visits
field_contact_button:language:
equipment and tutors?

Parents choose to educate their children at home for various reasons. Most think long and hard about this way of educating. For many parents and children
field_publish_date: home education is a rewarding and positive experience but it will undoubtedly change your life style. To do it properly is time-consuming and will affect of the organisation of your days
field_publish_date:timezone: and it may involve changes
field_publish_date:rrule:
such as giving up a job.

]]>

title: $Reasons for home educating$
body:
$4. What are my reasons for wanting to home educate my children?

For many home educating parents
body:summary:
it is part of a general philosophy on the way the family conduct their lives.

A minority of parents decide to withdraw their children from school because they may have had a disagreement with the headteacher or staff there. Their children may feel they are bullied
body:format: and some children may put pressure on parents to be allowed to stay at home
body:language: or they refuse to go to school. Most of these problems can be satisfactorily solved if they are discussed with the staff at the school or local authority
field_contact_button: who will give help and advice on how best to proceed
field_contact_button:title:
so think carefully before you withdraw your child from a school and do not be persuaded by others that it is the only option available to you.

]]>

title: $How to get started$
body:
$5. How to get started

Once all the advantages and disadvantages of home education have been discussed with the whole family and a final decision to go ahead has been made
body:summary: there may still remain a number of frequently-asked questions
body:format:
such as those listed below.

Children registered at a mainstream school

If your child is at a mainstream school you will need to inform the head teacher
body:language: in writing
field_contact_button: of your intention to deregister your child in order to home educate. You do not need permission to home educate
field_contact_button:title:
unless your child has a Statement of Special Educational Needs or Education Health Care Plan.

Children with Statement of Special Educational Needs or Education Health Care Plan who attends either a special school or mainstream school

If your child has a Statement of Special Educational Needs or Education Health Care Plan you will need to inform the head teacher in writing of your intention to home educate. However
field_contact_button:attributes:
the Local Authority (SEN department) will need to give consent for your child's name to be deleted from the school roll.

Do I need anyone’s permission?

No - only if your child has a Statement of Special Educational Needs or Education Health Care Plan..

]]>
field_contact_button:language: |">What are my reasons for wanting to home educate my child/ren?
field_publish_date: |">Provision of a suitable education]]>$

title: $Provision of a suitable education$
body:
$6. Provision of a suitable education

Do children educated otherwise have to follow the National Curriculum?

Parents are not legally required to do this. However some find it useful to know what the National Curriculum is and what children are taught in school.

The current National Curriculum subjects are listed below:

English
body:summary: mathematics
body:format: science
body:language: ICT (information & communication technology)
field_contact_button: history
field_contact_button:title: geography
field_contact_button:attributes: art
field_contact_button:language: DT (design & technology)
field_publish_date: physical education
field_publish_date:timezone: modern foreign languages (from age 11)
field_publish_date:rrule:
RE (religious education – unless parents exercise their right to withdraw their children).

What does ‘providing full-time education’ mean?

Currently schools work for 25 or 27.5 hours a week according to the ages of their pupils. Home educating parents are under no obligation to follow these hours and each family will vary in how they organise their days to ensure that enough time is spent on teaching and learning each week.

How should teaching and children’s learning be organised?

No one approach can be recommended. Parents should consider what the best teaching style is for themselves and for their children. Whatever style is adopted
field_publish_date:to:
it should allow children to become actively involved and provide opportunities for learning through practical activities and may well change over time.

What resources are available for use by parents and children? 

  • A range of books for reading for pleasure and information
  • Commercially produced workbooks related to the National Curriculum
  • Educational broadcasts (TV
field_expiry_date: radio) are useful
field_expiry_date:timezone: but to avoid the passive watching syndrome
field_expiry_date:rrule:
the programmes should be well prepared and followed up
  • Visits to interesting places (museums
field_expiry_date:to: theatres
field_site_section: exhibitions
field_site_section:source_type: historic sites
field_site_section:create_term: lectures
field_site_section:ignore_case: nature walks
field_service_hub:
etc)
  • Computer software with programmes for consolidating and extending learning in all subjects

    • Who should provide the education?

    Parents are responsible for ensuring that an efficient education is given. This requirement does not mean that they have to do all the teaching. Some of it can be done by suitable friends
field_service_hub:source_type:
with other home educating families or by private tutors.

How do I ensure my child receives an effective social education?

The development of social skills is an essential part of a balanced and efficient education. Learning activities out and about in the community gives children opportunities to experience social contacts
metatag_standout:
swimming and many more).

Can my child attend school part-time?

No. This is not considered viable as it blocks a place for a full-time pupil and has been found not to be in the best interests of the individual child. If children are receiving home education
metatag_generator:
they are not on a school’s register. In very exceptional circumstances governors of a school might consider making special arrangements for a short time only but the law is very clear that pupils must attend school or be educated otherwise.

Advice on examinations

Home educated children do not have to sit any Standard Assessment Tests (SATs) or GCSEs. It is possible however for home educated children to sit GCSEs if desired
metatag_rights:
although there is currently no funding from central government or the Local Authority.

There are a number of different examination boards that offer GCSE qualifications and each offer a variety of syllabuses. If your child wants to sit GCSE exams
metatag_image_src: you will need to find a centre that
metatag_shortlink: will allow your child to sit their exams there
metatag_publisher:
such as a school or college. You will need a copy of the exact exam syllabus to be studied for that year and Examinations boards can send you these and copies of previous exam papers for a fee.

]]>

title: $What can I expect from the Local Authority?$
body:
$7. What can I expect from the Local Authority?

Will the Local Authority support parents who decide to educate their children otherwise than in school?

Once you have decided to home educate your child/ren
body:summary: you are responsible for making suitable arrangements for their education. The Local Authority has a Home Education Adviser who is available to answer any questions and offer advice in relation to the provision you are making. The HEA will usually arrange to visit you or arrange to meet you at an alternative agreed venue to discuss the education you are providing and
body:format: if necessary
body:language:
give suggestions or recommendations on how what you are doing could be enhanced.

What does the Home Education Adviser look for when visiting the home?

The HEA will be interested to see how you are planning for what is to be taught and when. He or she will be interested to see examples of your child’s learning and to discuss with you any suggestions or concerns. The HEA will do this in a variety of ways:

  • through discussions with parents and children
  • listening to children talking about their work and what they have learnt
  • hearing children read and asking questions
  • looking at examples of written work
field_contact_button: art work
field_contact_button:title: models
field_contact_button:attributes: photographs
field_contact_button:language: electronic recordings and oral presentations ]]>

field_publish_date:timezone: |">What do other Elective Home Education parents and children have to say?]]>$

title: $Other Elective Home Education parents and children$
body:
$8. What do other Elective Home Education parents and children have to say?

These are some comments made by parents and children who are being home educated
body:summary:
in relation to their meetings with the HEA:

  • ‘She was so excited about your visit she couldn’t eat her dinner’. (Mother of child age 7)
  • ‘It’s so good to know that someone in the local authority really cares about what we do’. (Mother of secondary age child)
  • ‘Oh
body:format:
we were hoping you’d come round every month so we know we’re on the right lines’. (Father of girl age 13)
  • ‘It’s really good when you encourage her and it’s not just praise from us’. (Mother of 14 year old girl)
  • ‘Thank you for coming to see me
body:language: when it’s all inside you

title: $Alternatives to Exclusion$
body:
$3. Alternatives to Exclusion (including 'managed moves')

Headteachers should
body:summary: as far as possible
body:format: avoid excluding permanently any pupil with an Education
body:language: Health and Care Plan (EHC)
field_contact_button: a statement of SEN or a looked after child. Statutory guidance on strategies to be employed are covered in the DfE exclusions guidance (page 9
field_contact_button:title:
para. 21-23).

The guidance promotes the use of early intervention strategies by schools to address underlying causes of disruptive behaviour and avoid exclusions. Maintained schools have the power to direct a pupil off-site for education to improve his or her behaviour. Academies can place a pupil either full-time or part-time in another educational setting with parental agreement.

A pupil can also transfer to another school as part of a ‘managed move’ where this occurs with the consent of the parties involved
field_contact_button:attributes: including the parents. However
field_contact_button:language:
it must be stressed that the threat of exclusion must never be used to influence parents to remove their child from the school.

All such options can be discussed with the Tri-Borough Alternative Provision Service (TBAP).The Tri-Borough Alternative Provision Service (TBAP) works with learners from across the three boroughs that are experiencing difficulty with mainstream school and can provide schools with a menu of options.

TBAP Commissioning and School Support (CSS) is the single point of contact for secondary schools in the three boroughs to discuss all aspects of school based interventions or managed moves
field_publish_date:
where schools are actively considering possible alternatives to exclusion. Contact: 0203 108 0345.

If you wish to discuss possible school based interventions at primary level
field_publish_date:timezone:

$5. Arranging alternative provision (day 6 provision)

The local authority is responsible for arranging alternative education provision from the sixth school day following a permanent exclusion and must therefore be notified "without delay".

In addition to providing a copy of the letter notifying the parent of the decision to permanently exclude
body:summary:
all schools are required to complete the appropriate attached referral form (primary or secondary) which provides essential additional information (e.g. parental contact details) which will assist the local authority in meeting their statutory obligations.

body:format:
their ‘home’ authority must also be notified by the school "without delay" as that authority has the responsibility for providing day 6 provision).

Fixed-term exclusions over 5 days also require alternative provision from the sixth school day. The TBAP service provides this provision for secondary aged pupils
body:language:
and schools are required to complete the appropriate TBAP referral form.

Provision for fixed-term exclusions of more than 5 days for primary school pupils must be arranged between primary schools themselves.

$Making a homeless application

If you make a homeless application
body:summary: we will consider your individual circumstances to work out what
body:format: if any
body:language: housing duty is owed to you. The Council is obliged to assess your application under Part VII of the Housing Act 1996
field_contact_button:
as amended by Homelessness (Priority Need for Accommodation)(England) Order 2002.

We use national law and guidance to assess homelessness applications
field_contact_button:title:
including the Homelessness Code of Guidance for Local Authorities which is located on the government services and information website.

There are tests within the legislation that are applied to all homeless applications. These are known as the ‘threshold tests’. The four threshold tests you must meet to access social housing are:

  • eligible for assistance; AND
  • homeless or threatened with homelessness within 28 days; AND
  • in priority need; AND
  • NOT intentionally homeless

We will need to see certain documents to fully assess your application
field_contact_button:attributes: for example we need to know what your nationality is and if applicable

what your status is in the UK. Try to bring as many of these with you as you can:

  • Identification for all family members:

  • proof of pregnancy (if applicable)
  • proof of residency for the last five years
  • tenancy agreement

$How long does it take for a decision to be made on my homeless application?

This depends on your circumstances and the enquiries we need to make
body:summary:
so it varies from person to person. Some of the important factors are:

  • where you were living before
  • your reasons for being homeless
  • your social and medical circumstances.

These are just some of the things we need to look at when taking an application.

Will I automatically be given somewhere to live?

This depends on your individual circumstances. If we believe you are eligible

title: $When a decision is made$

$When a decision is made

If we decide that we do have a duty to provide you with accommodation
body:summary: we will do so until that duty ends. We will put your details on the Housing Register. This is a list of all people looking for social housing (which is housing run by the Council or housing associations). Once you are on the register
body:format: you can bid for properties that become available. The properties you can bid for will depend on the priority points we award you. For more information
body:language: visit our <a title="Visit our Social Housing page" href="ILINK|16787
field_contact_button:
|">social housing page.

Following a change in law (Localism Act 2011)
field_contact_button:title: councils are now able to offer suitable private rented accommodation to homeless households
field_contact_button:attributes: instead of social housing. Under the new law
field_contact_button:language: we are only required to make ONE offer of private rented accommodation to end our housing duty towards you. The property offered could be located anywhere in the UK
field_publish_date:
as long as we consider it to be suitable for your household’s needs.

To give you an alternative and greater choice about where you are rehoused
field_publish_date:timezone: the Council has developed the <a title="Private Rented Access Scheme" href="ILINK|16767
field_publish_date:rrule: |">Private Rented Access Scheme (PRAS). You will still move to private rented housing
field_publish_date:to:
but you find the accommodation rather than waiting for us to make an offer.

If we decide that we do not have a duty to continue housing you
field_expiry_date:
we will normally continue to provide accommodation for 28 days from the date of decision.

If I don’t meet the criteria to be rehoused
field_expiry_date:timezone:
what will happen then?

Unfortunately
field_expiry_date:rrule:
we are is unable to rehouse every single person who is homeless.

title: $How can I access supported housing?$

$How can I access supported housing?

You need to be referred to the Council for supported housing. Most referrals come from people who have some understanding of your needs and think that you would benefit from supported housing. The types of organisations that can refer you are:

  • the Council’s Housing Needs Department
  • the Council’s Adult Social Care teams
  • the Council's Children's Services
  • Community Mental Health Teams in the borough
  • Kensington and Chelsea Metropolitan Police
  • London Probation Service covering Kensington and Chelsea
  • registered social landlords (housing associations)
  • community organisations within Kensington and Chelsea.

You must:

  • be able to prove you have been living in Kensington and Chelsea and have an established connection with the borough
  • be homeless and/or in housing need.

title: $Who gets priority for social housing?$
body:
$Who will be given priority for housing?

The Council offers some priority to groups defined in law as needing to be given ‘reasonable preference’. This includes people:

  • who need to move on medical or welfare grounds
body:summary:
including needs relating to a disability
  • living in insanitary or overcrowded housing
body:format:
or otherwise living in unsatisfactory conditions
  • who are homeless
body:language:
including those who are not in priority need or who are intentionally   homeless
  • owed a duty under various sections of the Housing Act 1996 relating to homelessness.

    • The Council will also award priority to:

    • tenants already living in social housing (Council or housing association) who:
    • are looking to move from a property with two or more bedrooms to a property; (as larger properties are in short supply)
    • are living in a property that has been adapted for a disabled person and they no longer need those adaptations (the property can then be given to someone who does)
    • need to leave their accommodation because it is being demolished for redevelopment or significantly refurbished and the Council has an agreed plan to move them
    • people who have a legal right of succession to a Council or housing association property but have been asked to move as the property is too large for their needs
    • people suitable to foster or adopt one or more children but who need more appropriate accommodation in order to do so
    •  people living in supported accommodation or care provided or paid for by the Council who are ready to move to independent living and the Council has a duty to provide ongoing help
    • people to whom the Council or the Kensington and Chelsea Tenant Management Organisation owes a contractual duty to provide accommodation (for example
field_contact_button:
the accommodation relates to their job)
  • people who have exceptional and compelling circumstances and no other suitable housing options are available (including a homelessness application).

    • The Council will award additional priority to people:

    • who are in one or more priority categories listed above where the applicant
field_contact_button:title:
their partner or a member of their household is in paid work averaging 16 hours or more per week and has been in work continuously for at least six months
  • who fall within one or more of the statutory reasonable preference categories (see previous page) and have urgent housing needs
field_contact_button:attributes: and who are serving or former members of the Armed Services or their bereaved spouses or civil partners
field_contact_button:language: or serving or former members of the Reserve Forces. ]]>

$The new system is called Individual Electoral Registration. It means:

title: $There are two registers. Why?$
body: $Using information received from the public
body:summary:
registration officers keep two registers – the electoral register and the open register (also known as the edited register).

The electoral register lists the names and addresses of everyone who is registered to vote in public elections.

The register is used for electoral purposes – such as making sure only eligible people can vote – and for other limited purposes specified in law. The personal data in the register must always be processed in line with data-protection legislation.

Who uses the electoral register?

  • Election staff
body:format: political parties
body:language:
candidates and holders of elected office use the register for electoral purposes.
  • Your local council and the British Library hold copies that anyone may look at under supervision. A copy is also held by the Electoral Commission
field_contact_button:
the Boundary Commissions (which set constituency boundaries for most elections) and the Office for National Statistics.
  • The council can use the register for duties relating to security
field_contact_button:title:
enforcing the laws and preventing crime. The police and the security services can also use it for law enforcement.
  • The register is used when calling people for jury service.
  • Government departments may but the register form local registration officers and use it to help prevent and detect crime. They can also use it to safeguard national security by checking the background of job applicants and employees.
  • Credit reference agencies can buy the register. They help other organisations to check the names and addresses of people applying for credit. They also use it to carry out identity checks when trying to prevent and detect money laundering.

    • It is a criminal offence for anyone to supply or use the register for anything else.

    The open register is an extract of the electoral register
field_contact_button:attributes: but is not used for elections. It can be bought by any person
field_contact_button:language: company or organisation. For example
field_publish_date:
it is used by businesses and charities to confirm name and address details. The personal data in the register must always be processed in line with data protection legislation.

Your name and address will be included in the open register unless you ask for them to be removed. Removing your details from the open register would not affect your right to vote.

Who uses the open register?

Users of the open register include:

  • Businesses checking the identity and address details of people who apply for their services such as insurance
field_publish_date:timezone: goods hire and property rental
field_publish_date:rrule:
as well as when they shop online;
  • Businesses selling age-restricted goods or services
field_publish_date:to: such as alcohol and gambling online
field_expiry_date:
to meet the rules on verifying the age of their customers;
  • Charities and voluntary agencies
field_expiry_date:timezone:
for example to help maintain contact information for those who have chosen to donate bone marrow and to help people separated by adoption to find each other;
  • Charities
field_expiry_date:rrule:
to help with fund raising and contacting people who have made donations;
  • Debt collection agencies when tracing people who have changed address without telling their creditors;
  • Direct marketing firms when maintaining their mailing lists;
  • Landlords and letting agents when checking the identity of potential tenants;
  • Local councils when identifying and contacting residents;
  • Online directory firms to help users of the websites find people
field_expiry_date:to:
such as when reuniting friends and families;
  • Organisations tracing and identifying beneficiaries of wills
field_site_section:
pensions and insurance policies;
  • Private sector firms to verify details of job applicants.

body:
$The revised Green Binder for Support Staff

The revised 2011 Green Binder of Professional Frameworks for Support Staff grew out of the original Green Binder work that was completed in 2006. This revision reflects the Royal Borough's continued commitment to the professionalisation of our support staff body. It offers more flexibility allowing you to tweak generic documents (e.g. Job Descriptions
body:summary: Person Specifications etc.) to your context – and it is on the internet
body:format:
for greater ease of access.

In addition
body:language: the revised Royal Borough guidance reflects the National Occupational Standards for Support Staff. These describe what people need to be able to do
field_contact_button:
as well as what they must know and understand for their work. They are useful statements of competence describing good practice and they underpin Support Staff qualifications.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea value the huge contribution that Support Staff make to school and pupil outcomes. Such impact does not happen by chance but is the result of a practical strategy underpinned by the belief that the most effective support staff are learners themselves and highly reflective practitioners.  To have impact
field_contact_button:title: support staff must understand their role and have opportunities to develop their skills
field_contact_button:attributes: expertise
field_contact_button:language:
knowledge and understanding. The Royal Borough is committed to high quality performance management for all support staff.  It is through this professional dialogue that support staff are supported and challenged to be the very best for our children and young people.

In 2003
field_publish_date: there was a major national focus on developing support staff roles in schools to help to raise standards and to tackle workload issues. Across the country
field_publish_date:timezone: support staff increased – both the number of support staff and also the range of roles. In 2009
field_publish_date:rrule:
49 per cent of the school workforce in Kensington and Chelsea comprised support staff. The Royal Borough continues to support the professional development of this significant part of the school workforce.

body:summary: $School business managers are integral to the smooth and successful running of a school. Research shows that School Business Managers save schools money
body:format:
free up Head Teachers to focus on leading teaching and learning and have a direct impact on outcomes for children.

School business managers have significant responsibilities including:

  • the strategic and operational management of resources (financial
body:language:
human and facilities)
  • line management and professional development of support staff
  • marketing and communication.

    • School business managers often lead teams of administrative colleagues and many of today's most effective SBMs began their career in a school office as administrators. There is no "one size fits all" type of office team and each school has developed its own strategy to secure good administrative support for the organisation. To help schools to develop their office team
field_contact_button:
we have developed this 'Professional Framework' for School Administration and Business Support staff.

This Professional Framework draws upon National Occupational Standards (NOS) for school administrative staff. NOS are benchmarks of good practice which have been used here to develop Job Descriptions and to facilitate reflective practice as part of the performance management process. The 'Performance Management Trackers' can be used to focus dialogue between support staff and their line manager on successes and areas for professional development.

This Professional Framework has identified four distinctly different roles:

  • Administrative Assistant/ Receptionist
  • Administrative Officer
  • Senior Administrative Officer
  • Business Operations Manager

title: $Corporate Services Innovative Projects Funding$
body:
$Corporate Services Innovative Projects Funding

The Royal Borough launched a new funding stream for innovative projects as part of the Corporate Grants Scheme in 2012. 

The Council made grants available to voluntary organisations for up to a three year period from April 2013
body:summary:
and sought interest from local groups based on the following criteria:

  • offering a new service in the Royal Borough
  • being delivered by a new provider (not in receipt of Corporate Services Grants Programme funding)
  • reaching a new client group
  • offering a convincing possibility of being sustainable with little or no public sector subsidy within three years

Proposals also needed to demonstrate how they would contribute to the achievement of one or more of the following Council priorities:

  • tackling social isolation identified in a range of groups
body:format:
not only older people
  • supporting residents to improve their life chances through work and skills; and
  • encouraging community resilience through greater neighbourliness
body:language:
civic participation and self-help

Organisations were invited to submit business cases that met the funding criteria for the projects that they wanted to deliver.

View more information about the funding criteria [PDF] (file size 1.11Mb)

The first round of funding was launched in 2013-14 when seven projects were successful in securing innovative project funding. 

 In 2014-15 there was a second round of funding where eight more projects were allocated funding for two years although since then two have ceased. There are currently thirteen projects being delivered through this fund.

View the grant allocations here [PDF] (file size 59kb)

 The Council has not announced a new round of funding for innovative projects in 2015-16
field_contact_button:
and is working with those organisations currently funded to ensure their sustainability and success.

For more information about the Corporate Services Innovative Projects Funding contact the Community Engagement Team on:

Email: communityengagement@rbkc.gov.uk

Help - A Click Away - Can you help the Library's computer users to use their computers more effectively?

Tri-Borough Libraries and Arts Service are running sessions in Kensington Central Library to help people resolve particular computer issues they might have. They can book 1 hour slots to resolve issues such as working with attachments

IT Tutor

This role involves working with people in the library who are interested in improving their IT skills. You will work from computers dedicated to training activities. We are flexible about how you work with your students so you can have some input into what you do - from teaching small classes about IT basics and having a set lesson plan

Sunday: Mornings

Afternoons

Homework Club Mentor

Do you want to make a positive and lasting contribution to the lives of children aged 7 to 11?

We are looking for a wide range of people to help us to deliver the Homework Club offer; acting as 'Homework Club Mentors' to children. You will be based in the library of your choice as part of a team of volunteers; assisting children with their English and maths homework as well as other subjects and enabling children to develop valuable study skills. You may also be participating in a one to one setting within the session i.e. listening to a child read. 

Volunteering to deliver the Homework Club offer will involve:

  • Assisting with administration duties
  • Talking with children about their homework. 
  • Supporting children to complete their homework
  • Listening to them read and encouraging them to share their views and ideas 
  • Developing a good understanding of our libraries e.g. the types of books available; how to
  • find books using the online search catalogue; where to find books

Working alongside a tutor

More general duties will include:

  • Liaising directly with learners in terms of booking learning places

This project aims to develop the capabilities of the adult learners and so to improve their quality of life. Your contribution will be important and valued!

metatag_robots:

$Business Rates

Capita manage the business rates bills on behalf of the Council and they send out the bills and collect the money.

Mandatory Rate Relief

This is a national government scheme which provides relief on the business rates of registered charitable organisations.  Relief of 80% on rate bills is provided for eligible charities and this is called mandatory relief.

For more information on mandatory rate relief please
body:format:
contact|">contact Business Rates  

Discretionary Rate Relief (DRR)

In addition to mandatory rate relief
body:language:
the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea operates a local policy of Discretionary Rate Relief (DRR) which provides an additional discount of up to 10% for organisations that receive mandatory relief and up to 90% for not-for-profit organisations that do not receive mandatory relief; this is based on percentages of service users that are RBKC residents.

All organisations wishing to apply for DRR must ensure that they meet the criteria and then fill in an application form. The application form must provide evidence of the percentage of service users that are RBKC residents.  Organisations are allocated DRR for an initial two year period after which a renewal form will need to be submitted every two years.  New applications can be backdated to the beginning of the financial year in which they are submitted.

title: $Art on Loan: information for businesses$
body: $The Council has launched a new initiative this year to build upon the success of the Art on Show project. Under the scheme
body:summary: local businesses that sign up to the programme will be able to hire or purchase original artworks created by students studying in the borough
body:format:
to enhance their office spaces.

The work is presented to professional gallery standards
body:language:
and businesses are able to choose artworks directly from the Schools Art on Show Exhibition in June. Taking part in the programme offers a unique opportunity for businesses to link Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) with an enhanced working environment and employee wellbeing.

Watch this short film to find out how the programme works:

The benefits

The Schools Art on Show project provides an ideal opportunity for businesses to meet Corporate Social Responsibility targets
field_contact_button: by supporting art departments in the borough’s schools
field_contact_button:title: giving a sense of purpose to young artists studying in the borough
field_contact_button:attributes:
and supporting development of an innovative project at Leighton House Museum.

Students whose work is selected by a business through the programme will receive recognition that can be included in their portfolio or CV
field_contact_button:language:
and so contributing to their professional development.

Research demonstrates that staff are more productive if they can tailor their surroundings to their needs and preferences. Employees can be invited to view the works during the Exhibition in June and choose pieces for their office spaces
field_publish_date: offering a mechanism for staff to personally select artworks for their working environment. Changing the artwork regularly through hiring the work increases the opportunity for staff engagement and ownership of their surroundings; or if a piece is well liked by all
field_publish_date:timezone:
a business is able to purchase available pieces too.

Hiring artworks through the programme also offers a practical solution for businesses operating in flexible or short-term contemporary offices designed to be reconfigured as and when
field_publish_date:rrule:
and complements flexible working arrangements. Participating businesses will also benefit from marketing opportunities associated with being part of the programme.

How it works

Each piece on loan or purchased will come with an accompanying caption with information about the Schools Art on Show programme
field_publish_date:to: which can be displayed alongside the piece. This demonstrates clearly to clients and external visitors that the business is participating in the programme. Further marketing opportunities could include mention of participating businesses in publicity produced by the Council
field_expiry_date: features in case studies used to promote the programme
field_expiry_date:timezone:
and on the Council's website.

Income generated through artwork hire fees paid by participating businesses is split between covering costs and a contribution to schools and/or students whose artwork is on loan to businesses. Income generated from artwork sales directly from the Exhibition will go to the artist
field_expiry_date:rrule: minus a small commission which will cover the costs of administering the sale. As the Schools Art on Show programme for businesses develops
field_expiry_date:to:
a proportion of the income could be set aside for developing future sustainability for the Art on Show project or increasing access to arts activities for young people in the borough.

Artworks will be available and ready to hang from July 2015.

To get involved or for further information contact Jennifer Wood in the Council’s Arts Service via email Jennifer.Wood@rbkc.gov.uk or on 020 7361 4378.
